title: Can we keep sodium in water? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sodium was first isolated by electrolysis of SODIUM HYDROXIDE.Sodium lies in group 1 denoted by Na and its atomic number is 11 relative atomic mass is 22.9 that we say 23 also belongs to “s” block element. Sodium is a soft metal that tarnishes within a seconds of being exposed to the air. It also reacts vigorously with water. Sodium is used as a heat exchanger in some nuclear reactor and as a reagent in chemical companies now the question raised in your mind why it tarnish when exposed to air or react vigorously with water. Ques: Why it tarnish when exposed to air or react vigorously with water? Here we go with the answer. Sodium belong to the family of Alkali elements.Alkali metals are all shiny, soft highly reactive metal at standard temperature and pressure and readily loses their outer most electron to form cations with charge +1. It tarnish when exposed to air to perform combustion and oxidation wit the help of oxygen and moisture present in air.Sodium is a very active element. It combines with oxygen at room temperature. When heated, it combines very rapidly, burning with a brilliant golden-yellow flameSodium also reacts violently with water. (See accompanying sidebar.) It is so active that it is normally stored under a liquid with which it does not react. Kerosene or naphtha are liquids commonly used for this purpose. Sodium also reacts with most other elements and with many compounds. It reacts with acids to produce hydrogen gas. It also dissolves in Mercury to form a sodium amalgam. An amalgam is an alloy of mercury and at least one other metal Now imagine there is only Na around you ?

All the alkali metals are reactive in nature but (Na)Sodium highly reactive in nature it react with water H2O and form NaOH this reaction is an exothermic reaction means a lot of heat released during this reaction it act as a explosive due to this it can not stored in water In some nuclear reactor Na is used as a heat transfers fluid and insides hollow valves of high performance internal combustion engine It is discovered by sir Humphrey Davy in 1807 Na is soft and silverywhite in colour It is stored in kerosene

Na is the most reactive metal. Na cannot be stored in water, because Na and H2O reacts very fast, it is an highly exothermic process. In reaction of Na and H2O, hydrogen gas is produced which catches fire, due to heat released during this process. 2Na + 2H2O → 2NaOH + H2. In order to prevent fire, Na is stored in kerosene.

Strictly no. You cannot keep sodium in water. Explosive reaction will occur within fraction of seconds. This type of reaction is very common lab experiment and everybody know about it. Sodium is usually kept in kerosene to avoid it to come in contact with oxygen and moisture. For more information you can read the following link. Watch Sodium Explode In Water At 10,000 Frames Per Second

No. Sodium cannot be stored or kept in water because it is alkali metal or you can say group 1 element. Elements of this group are highly reactive towards water and their reactivity increases as we go down the group. To see how it reacts with water you can search on YouTube. Type “Reaction of alkali elements towards water” and you can see how all the elements react.

No… that would lead to a great mishap… sodium reacts rapidly with water to form sodium hydroxide(caustic soda) and Hydrogen gas…. And the hydrogen gas can catch fire cause of the huge amount of heat involved in this chemical reaction…. The reaction appears more like an explosion and things go out of control easily based on the amount of sodium you are trying to put into water.

Ans is no… Because sodium is one of the most electropositive metal will small size.. So is vary reactive and reacts violently with water causing explosion.. So we can't keep ‘Na’ metal in water.. Again from standard reduction potential chart ‘Na’ have the potential to replace ‘H’ from water.. Forming ‘NaOH’ with excessive release of energy.. If u want u can store it in kerosene..

NO,sodium acts vigorous with water it should not be kept in http://water.it will produce spark like glowing when it is placed in water.it is a good reducing agent and reacts with the moisture in the air.due to that reason it was kept in kerosene which was not easy to reduce..

U can't keep sodium metal as such in water … Bcz sodium metal is highly reactive to water . It pops out with a huge hissing sound {if u add more sodium to water } ..That's y mostly metals r stored in amber coloured bottles , to resist it from sunlight and other external factors If u want to save sodium in water. , I have a different idea…

Obviously you can, but what happens later is interesting yet dangerous. The sodium atoms are highly reactive and will burn even when kept in open air. Therefore one can imagine what happens when it is put in water. The reaction shall proceed violently. If one wants to preserve sodium, kerosene should be used.

Hmmm… Try it out for yourself. All the best!!  source: Sodium in Water Explosion | Chemical Reaction - 
ronnie white Basically what happens is that the Sodium reacts with water molecules to release H2H2 which self ignites and results in a massive but short lived explosion (depending on amount of sodium and the structure distribution)

Sodium is more reactive Since it has only one electron in its outer orbit Its reacts vigorously with water Na + H2O →NaOH Simply a alkali metal reacts with water to form a base Sodium piece when dropped in water it looks like it is pop dancer! Dont even touch sodium with a bare hand It reacts with moisture on your finger It may hurt because of its high heat of hydration So it is stored under kerosene Preventing its exposure from moisture is suggestible

Hehe. If you want to keep sodium in water. Just try it to see instant explosion. Sodium (Na) is an alkaline metal . When it comes in contact of water. Hydrogen removes instantly from water and form NaOH. This is an highly exothermic reaction. That's why we see instant explosion. Hence, sodium kept in kerosene instead of water.

NOOOOOO its highly reactive metal. As soon as sodium comes in contact with water its starts exothermic(reaction with release of heat) reaction and one of its by product is hydrogen gas which is highly combustible. TIP if you have sodium then even if you kept in open air it starts reaction so keep it dipped in Kerosene Oil.

Sodium belongs to the alkali metal family. It is a highly reactive metal and it reacts with water very vigorously. The reaction of sodium with water is highly exothermic. Sodium burns instantaneously as it comes in contact with water. That's why sodium in kept in kerosene. And we have to be very careful while doing an experiment with sodium .

No , sodium is not stored in water it is a metal that lies in the high ranking of activity series and when it is added to a vigerous reaction occur and suddenly the water rotates and a fire catch on the piece of sodium and huge amount of heat and water vapour evolves. Hence sodium cannot be stored in water

Sodium is alkali metal,it has very low value of std reduction potential (negative).When it comes in contact with water,it ultimately displaces hydrogen forming NaOH. Reaction is highly exothermic, thus activity of sodium may get changed. Hence it is kept in kerosene.

Elementary sodium reacts strongly with water, according to the following reaction mechanism: 2Na(s) + 2H2O → 2NaOH(aq) + H2(g) Also sodium in different states are water soluble. Therefore sodium cannot be stored in water Read more: https://www.lenntech.com/periodic/water/sodium/sodium-and-water.htm#ixzz4zssVWPOS

No, we can not keep Sodium in Water as it is very reactive to water to form Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH) and liberate hydrogen gas, which due to reaction heat catches fire and burn very spontaneously and can be very dangerous and harmful. So it is kept in Kerosine, which is unreactive to Na and thus can be kept safely.

No. We shouldn’t keep Sodium in water. Since sodium is a soft metal which is immersed in kerosene to improve its properties, it gains some energy. So when it contacts with water, it releases energy. 2Na + 2H2O → H2 + 2NaOH

No,we cant because sodium is a highly reactive metal and it reacts rapidly with oxygen,and water contains oxygen(H2O). For that very reason sodum is stored in kerosene to avoid direct contact with oxygen…… Was this answer helpful??☺

Sodium is a highly reducing metal (for Na→Na+ + e-, E0=+2.71) and thus will give away its electrons to anything less reducing than itself (which is most things!). The practical upshot of this is that it will react with moisture in the air: Na + H2O → NaOH + 1/2 H2 And with Oxygen: 2Na + 1/2 O2 → Na2O Basically it’s kept in things which aren’t so easily reduced (long chain hydrocarbons like kerosene, where the carbon is already in a very low formal oxidation state) which also expel moisture.

No certainly not or I must say definitely not if you don't want to get burnt as sodium is an alkali metal which means it has 1 electron in its outermost shell it is very reactive as it can very easily kick off that one electron so it readily reacts with dissolved impurities or any gases like oxygen in water and burst into flames spontaneously.

Sodium is very reactive metal . It can’t be kept in water otherwise it will form NA+WATER= NAOH+h2. No we can not keep sodium in water because it burn with red flame sodium react with oxygen present in water and burn mostly sodium keep in kerosine there is no presence of oxygen therefore it is good to keep in kerosine

No. If you keep sodium in water, it will react vigorously with water to form sodium hydroxide and liberate hydrogen gas as well as heat. Due to this generated heat, liberated Hydrogen gas will catch fire!

Sodium in contact with water will form sodium hydroxide. It's an exothermic reaction and will generate huge amount of heat which may cause fatal accidents. So we can not keep sodium in water
No, sodium can not be kept in water because reaction of sodium and water is highly exothermic. During this reaction hydrogen gas is produced which catches fire due to heat released during reaction.

No never do this!! Sodium is the most reactive metal in all metals available. Also it is harmful to the human being. When we put sodium in water it catches higly explosive fire. Sodium should be kept in kerosene.

No, because sodium is very reactive metal and it reacts vigorously with water replaces hydrogen and forms NaOH. This is a highly exothermic process. It is kept in kerosene to avoid catching fire. Sodium catches fire even when kept in air.

No absolutely not. It will catch fire and burn very vigorously. I had a personal experience with sodium metal. My hand had small droplets of water and I was cutting sodium. A small bit stuck to my hand and left a second degree burn. Hence sodium metal is stored in kerosene.
No we can't keep sodium in water . This is because on reaction of water with sodium results in release of hydrogen and intense heat .Due to this it allows hydrogen to catch fire.

No, Na is very reactive alkali metal and in water it forms NaOH. This reaction is highly exothermic. In the presence of air, it reacts with oxygen and immediately catches fire. Therefore, it is stored in kerosene.

Acids are soluble in water. When an acid is dissolved in water, a dilute solution of the acid is formed and heat is given out. For this reason it is dangerous to add water to acid. To dilute an acid always add acid to water slowly, with constant stirring. So, the answer is yes
